column1: |409 u.s. 249|"Executive Jet Aviation v. City of Cleveland

column2: invoking federal admiralty jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C.  1333(1)
column3: brought suit for damages resulting from the crash-landing and sinking in the navigable waters of Lake Erie of their jet aircraft shortly after takeoff from a Cleveland airport.  The District Court dismissed the complaint for lack of admiralty jurisdiction on the grounds that the alleged tort had neither a maritime locality nor a maritime nexus.  The Court of Appeals affirmed on the first ground.

column1: Held:  Neither the fact that an aircraft goes down on navigable waters nor that the negligence ""occurs"" while the aircraft is flying over such waters is sufficient to confer federal admiralty jurisdiction over aviation tort claims
column2: and
column3: in the absence of legislation to the contrary
column4: such jurisdiction exists with respect to those claims only when there is a significant relationship to traditional maritime activity.  Therefore
column5: federal admiralty jurisdiction does not extend to aviation tort claims arising from flights like the one involved here between points within the continental United States.  Pp.  409 U. S. 253-274.

column2: affirmed.
J.
column3: delivered the opinion for a unanimous Court.

column9: who were not entitled to reinstatement if the employer had substantial business justifications for refusing to rehire them.

column4: issued a policy of life insurance in 1938 to German Lopez Sanchez

column6: which were then recognized as one of two legal currencies in Cuba. But on June 30
column8: the government of Cuba suspended the legal tender status of the dollar and decreed that all previously contracted dollar obligations would henceforth be payable exclusively in Cuban pesos at the rate of one peso per dollar. column11: it notified the insured that '[a]ll permiums payable in accordance with this policy as well as all other liability contracted under the same and in which a reference is made to American currency

column15: and made all subsequent payments entirely in pesos. By legislation in 1959 and 1961 the Cuban Government reconfirmed the 1951 decree and provided criminal penalties for its violation. Petitioner

column5: the court concluded that petitioner was obligated to pay the benefits in Florida and in United States dollars. de Lara v. Confederation Life Assn.

It must by the previous September declare its intention to nominate by convention. That entails a state-wide party organization with an executive committee. It also requires the filing with the Secretary of State by February of the names of the candidates; it requires the filing of party rules by March. column2: hired for a fixed term of one academic year to teach at a state university
column3: was informed without explanation that he would not be rehired for the ensuing year.  A statute provided that all state university teachers would be employed initially on probation
column4: and that only after four years' continuous service would teachers achieve permanent employment ""during efficiency and good behavior
column5: with procedural protection against separation.  University rules gave a nontenured teacher ""dismissed"" before the end of the year some opportunity for review of the ""dismissal
column6: but provided that no reason need be given for nonretention of a nontenured teacher
column7: and no standards were specified for reemployment.  Respondent brought this action claiming deprivation of his Fourteenth Amendment rights
column8: alleging infringement of (1) his free speech right because the true reason for his nonretention was his criticism of the university administration
column9: and (2) his procedural due process right because of the university's failure to advise him of the reason for its decision.  The District Court granted summary judgment for the respondent on the procedural issue.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  The Fourteenth Amendment does not require opportunity for a hearing prior to the nonrenewal of a nontenured state teacher's contract unless he can show that the nonrenewal deprived him of an interest in ""liberty"" or that he had a ""property"" interest in continued employment
column2: despite the lack of tenure or a formal contract.  Here
column3: the nonretention of respondent
column4: absent any charges against him or stigma or disability foreclosing other employment
column5: is not tantamount to a deprivation of ""liberty
column6: and the terms of respondent's employment accorded him no ""property"" interest protected by procedural due process.  The courts below therefore erred in granting summary judgment for the respondent on the procedural due process issue.  Pp.  408 U. S. 569-579.

column2: reversed and remanded.

column1: This action was brought to compel the Attorney General to grant a temporary nonimmigrant visa to a Belgian journalist and Marxian theoretician whom the American plaintiff appellees had invited to participate in academic conferences and discussions in this country.  The alien had been found ineligible for admission under  212(a)(28)(D) and (G)(v) of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952
column2: barring those who advocate or publish ""the economic
column3: international
column4: and governmental doctrines of world communism.""  The Attorney General had declined to waive ineligibility as he has the power to do under  212(d) of the Act
column5: basing his decision on unscheduled activities engaged in by the alien on a previous visit to the United States
column6: when a waiver was granted.  A three-judge District Court
column7: although holding that the alien had no personal entry right
column8: concluded that citizens of this country had a First Amendment right to have him enter and to hear him
column9: and enjoined enforcement of  212 as to this alien.

column1: Held:  In the exercise of Congress' plenary power to exclude aliens or prescribe the conditions for their entry into this country
column2: Congress in  212(a)(28) of the Act has delegated conditional exercise of this power to the Executive Branch. When
column3: as in this case
column4: the Attorney General decides for a legitimate and bona fide reason not to waive the statutory exclusion of an alien
column5: courts will not look behind his decision or weigh it against the First Amendment interests of those who would personally communicate with the alien.  Pp.  408 U. S. 761-770.

column2: reversed.

column1: This is a class action for injunctive and declaratory relief by a child and mother whose husband is away from home on military duty
column2: challenging the validity of California's Department of Social Welfare Regulation EAS  42-350.11
column3: pursuant to which they had been denied Aid to Families With Dependent Children (AFDC) benefits.  Though California incorporates in its AFDC eligibility provisions the ""continued absence"" concept of the Social Security Act
column4: under which a dependent child ""deprived of parental support . . . by reason of [a parent's] continued absence from the home
column5: is deemed eligible for AFDC benefits
column6: EAS  42-350.11 excludes absence because of military service from the definition of ""continued absence.""  The District Court granted the relief sought.

column1: Held:  Section 402(a)(10) of the Social Security Act imposes on each State participating in the AFDC program the requirement that benefits ""shall be furnished with reasonable promptness to all eligible individuals.""  Under the Act
column2: the eligibility criterion of ""continued absence"" of a parent from the home means that the parent may be absent for any reason.  Consequently
column3: that criterion applies to one who is absent by reason of military service
column4: and California's definition is invalid under the Supremacy Clause.  Pp. 600-604.

column2: affirmed.
J.

column1: This is a class action for injunctive and declaratory relief by a child and mother whose husband is away from home on military duty
column2: challenging the validity of California's Department of Social Welfare Regulation EAS  42-350.11
column3: pursuant to which they had been denied Aid to Families With Dependent Children (AFDC) benefits.  Though California incorporates in its AFDC eligibility provisions the ""continued absence"" concept of the Social Security Act
column4: under which a dependent child ""deprived of parental support . . . by reason of [a parent's] continued absence from the home
column5: is deemed eligible for AFDC benefits
column6: EAS  42-350.11 excludes absence because of military service from the definition of ""continued absence.""  The District Court granted the relief sought.

column1: Held:  Section 402(a)(10) of the Social Security Act imposes on each State participating in the AFDC program the requirement that benefits ""shall be furnished with reasonable promptness to all eligible individuals.""  Under the Act
column2: the eligibility criterion of ""continued absence"" of a parent from the home means that the parent may be absent for any reason.  Consequently
column3: that criterion applies to one who is absent by reason of military service
column4: and California's definition is invalid under the Supremacy Clause.  Pp. 600-604.

column1: I would grant the petition for a writ of certiorari and either reverse out of hand or put the case down for argument.

By a 1903 Treaty the United States obtained a corridor across the Republic of Panama from the Caribbean to the Pacific. 33 Stat. 2234. But Art. VI of the Treaty provided that the grants to the United States shall not 'interfere with the rights of way over the public roads passing through the said zone . . . unless said rights of way or private rights shall conflict with rights herein granted to the United States in which case the rights of the United States shall be superior.' 33 Stat. 2234; 3 Canal Zone Code pp. 428

Petitioner is a Panamanion who has been operating buses in Panama for 23 years. His license to operate was granted by the Republic of Panama and his area of operation begins and ends in the Republic of Panama. Under a reciprocal agreement between the Canal Zone and Panama any motor vehicle inspected in Panama will be accepted in the Canal Zone and vice versa.
The public road travelled by petitioner crosses the Canal Zone and his operations in no way conflict with 'any rights granted to the United States' under the 1903 Treaty.

The Canal Zone authorities decided to give all cross-Canal Zone public transportation to one Delaware corporation. The necessity of the Delaware corporation's meeting minimum wage requirements was said to be the reason. No hearings
column2: however
column3: were held. The petitioner and the other 'indigents' were given no notice and no opportunity to be heard. They were driven out of business by the ipse dixit of the Governor and petitioner stands criminally convicted. Petitioner is no fly-by-night operator. He operated 15 buses and employed 30 people and was in this business for 23 years. His crossing of the Canal Zone is guaranteed by the 1903 Treaty; and though one agrees arguendo that the right may be regulated as to times and circumstances
column4: there is no defensible reason given why a person should be driven out of business with no chance to be heard.

column5: and Art. VI
column7: are not inconsistent with the First Amendment.  Pp.  405 U. S. 681-682.

column2: a paraphrase of the constitutional oath
column3: is permissible.  P.  405 U. S. 683.

column2: but was to assure that those in positions of public trust were willing to commit themselves to live by the constitutional processes of our government.  Pp.  405 U. S. 683-685.

column1: (d) The oath is not void for vagueness.  Perjury
column2: the sole punishment
column3: requires a knowing and willful falsehood

column6: as there has been no prosecution under the statute since its enactment
column7: nor has any been planned.  Pp.  405 U. S. 685-686.

column1: (e) There is no constitutionally protected right to overthrow a government by force
column2: violence
column3: or illegal or unconstitutional means
column4: and therefore there is no requirement that one who refuse to take Massachuetts' oath be granted a hearing for the determination of some other fact before being dicharged.  Pp. 686-687.

column1: Tennessee closes its registration books 30 days before an election
column2: but requires residence in the State for one year and in the county for three months as prerequisites for registration to vote.  Appellee challenged the constitutionality of the durational residence requirements
column3: and a three-judge District Court held them unconstitutional on the grounds that they impermissibly interfered with the right to vote and created a ""suspect"" classification penalizing some Tennessee residents because of recent interstate movement.  Tennessee asserts that the requirements are needed to insure the purity of the ballot box and to have knowledgeable voters.

column1: Held:  The durational residence requirements are violative of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
column2: as they are not necessary to further a compelling state interest.  Pp.  405 U. S. 335-360.

column1: (a) Since the requirements deny some citizens the right to vote
column2: ""the Court must determine whether the exclusions are necessary to promote a compelling state interest.""  Kramer v. Union Free School District
column4: 395 U. S. 627 (emphasis added).  Pp.  405 U. S. 336-337.

column2: Tennessee may not burden the right to travel by penalizing those bona fide residents who have recently traveled from one jurisdiction to another.  Pp.  405 U. S. 338-342.

column1: (c) A period of 30 days appears to be ample to complete whatever administrative tasks are needed to prevent fraud and insure the purity of the ballot box.  Pp.  405 U. S. 345-349.
(d) Since there are adequate means of ascertaining bona fide residence on an individualized basis
column2: the State may not conclusively presume nonresidence from failure to satisfy the waiting period requirements of durational residence laws.  Pp.  405 U. S. 349-354.

column1: (e) Tennessee has not established a sufficient relationship between its interest in an informed electorate and the fixed durational residence requirements.  Pp.  405 U. S. 354-360.

column1: The Court vacates the judgment of the Court of Appeals and directs that the Court of Appeals consider the views of the United States presented in this case. Finding the suggestions of the United States unacceptable
column2: I dissent from today's judgment.

column3: in response to the petition for certiorari
column5: asserted that in passing on petitioner's conscientious objector's claim the Army considered petitioner's opposition to war to be sincere and rejected the claim solely because peti-

column1: tioner's views did not qualify as religious under the standards of Welsh v. United States
column2: 398 U.S. 333 (1970). It was therefore error
column3: the United States urged
column4: for the Court of Appeals to have put aside the Welsh issue and to have affirmed the denial of habeas corpus on insincerity grounds after making an 'independent search of the administrative record' to discover a basis in fact for such a judgment.

column1: These assertions were incredible. The Army Review Board
column2: in its final order entered on September 10
column5: unanimously found that '1LT Rosengart's purported conscientious objector beliefs are not truly held; and that any objection to war in any form he might sincerely hold is based soley on philosophical and sociological experiences.' The plain meaning of this order is that the Board both found that petitioner was not sincere and determined that his views were solely philosophical and sociological.

column1: The Court of Appeals so read the Board's order
column2: saying '[t]he Board found that any conscientious objection held by Rosengart was based solely on philosophical views and sociological experiences (a curious finding in light of Welsh) and that Rosengart's 'purported conscientious objector beliefs are not truly held."" The Court of Appeals then put aside the issue of whether defendant's beliefs were religious within the meaning of the Act and affirmed the denial of habeas corpus after agreeing with the District Court that there was a basis in fact for a conclusion of insincerity because the record 'cast a cloud upon the sincerity of his professed deeply-held beliefs of conscientious objection.'

column1: There was nothing untoward in the way the Court of Appeals approached the case
column2: particularly since the United States in its October 13 memorandum flatly asserted that there was indeed sufficient evidence in the record to support the judgment of insincerity and that 'under normal circumstances
column3: such evidence would
column5: provide ample factual basis for a denial of petitioner's application for discharge.'

column2: the United States filed a supplemental memorandum on December 10
column4: modifying its position. It now concedes the dual basis of the Board's order and that '[v]iewed solely in light of the September 10 Board decision
column5: the majority's conclusion in this regard is not unwarranted.' It also reveals that '[i]ndeed
column6: such a result was suggested by the government's argument below . . ..' Nevertheless
column7: although again not disagreeing 'with the conclusion reached by the majority below that there was basis in fact on this record to sustain a finding of 'insincerity' with respect to petitioner's claimed opposition to war
column8: ' the Government's position in the Court of Appeals is characterized as placing 'undue emphasis on the final recommendation of the Army Review [909-Continued.]

column1: Board.' It is now urged that the Board's September 10 decision be read in conjunction with earlier decisions and that in context the Board be deemed to have found petitioner to be sincere.

I find nothing to commend the Government's position in this case. It would be one thing if it forthrightly supported petitioner's sincerity. It is quite another thing to assert that the record supports a judgment of insincerity
column2: and then
column3: notwithstanding this concession
column4: to urge setting aside the final order of the Army Review Board which plainly found petitioner insincere and which the United States does not straightforwardly argue was beyond the power of the Board.

column1: At the trial in this case there was much evidence of corrupt practices by the mayoral administration of petitioner Addonizio during his tenure as mayor of Newark
column2: New Jersey. But the question posed to the

column1: jury below was not whether these petitioners had engaged in corrupt practices but the narrower issue of whether these defendants had entered into and executed a criminal agreement to extract kickbacks from public contractors through threats of physical harm or economic ruin in violation of 18 U.S.C. 1951.1 Although the petitioners were charged with 65 substantive acts of coercive extraction of kickbacks
column2: the key issue in the trial was who
column3: if anyone
column4: had conspired to commit these acts. Absent a finding that such a confederation had been formed most of the evidence which damaged the petitioners could not have been introduced at all inasmuch as this evidence was hearsay admitted provisionally under the so- called coconspirator exception. That the jury found a conspiracy to have existed
column5: however
